question: Differentiate $y(x)=\displaystyle{(4-x^3)e^{5x}}$.
Let $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ be the linear operator given by  $T(x,y,z)=(x-2z,-2x+y+5z,4x+2y-6z)$. Indicate which of the following vectors does not belong to the range of $T$.
Consider $T:V \longrightarrow W$ a linear transformation and assume $dim(range(T))=3$. Choose the right answer.

Given a number $n \geq 1$, it can be represented as the following array of length $n$:
$$n = (1,\, 1,\, 1,\, 1,\, \dots,\, 1)$$
Suppose we are playing a game in which at each step we can advance one entry or two entries of the array. This leads us to a way of representing $n$ as a sum of natural numbers.

As an example, consider $n=5$ and the steps $1,\, 2,\, 2$. Then we get

$5 = (1 $ $\color{red} |$ $ 1 + 1 $ $\color{red} | $ $ 1 + 1)$, this is, $5 = 1 + 2 + 2$.

Note we are considering that, for example, $5 = 1+2+2$ is different from $5 = 2+1+2$.

Find the number of ways of doing this division.
Which matrix has linearly dependent rows?
Find $y'$ when $y = \dfrac{\sin(3t)}{\cos(t) + t}$.
Classify the critical points of $f(x,y)=x^3-3xy+y^3$.
answer1: $(1,1)$ is a minimum and $(0,0)$ is a saddle point.
answer2: $(1,1)$ is a saddle point and $(0,0)$ is a minimum.
answer3: $(1,1)$ and $(-1,-1)$ are a saddle points and $(0,0)$ is a minimum.
answer4: $(1,1)$ and $(-1,-1)$ are minima and $(0,0)$ is a saddle point.

Consider the function $f(x,y) = x^5y + 7y^3$. Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}$.
Find the flux of $\textbf{F}$ across S, where $\displaystyle\textbf{F}(x,y,z)=x\textbf{i}+2y\textbf{j}+3z\textbf{k}\,$, where S is the cube with vertices $\displaystyle(\pm 1, \pm 1, \pm 1)$.

For each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, describe the solutions of the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

question:
Solve for $x$:

$\frac{2x}{4}=3x^3$
Consider $x=\cos(x)$. Find $x_4$ using Newton's method considering $x_0=1$.

At the HealthPlus hospital, the nursing staff works in $6$ different shifts. Each shift has a duration of $8$ hours, with its start interval of $4$ hours (the first shift starts at $8:00$ AM, the second at $12:00$ AM, the third at $4:00$ p.m., and so on). The number of nurses required during the day is in the following table. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning the nursing staff, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of nurses working in shift $i~(i = 1~to~6)$?

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|}
\hline
\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of nurses} \\
\hline
\text{8:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m.} & 140 \\
\text{12:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 120 \\
\text{4:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.} & 160 \\
\text{8:00 p.m. to 12:00 p.m.} & 90 \\
\text{12:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m.} & 30 \\
\text{4:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 60 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
answer2:
\[
		\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^5 x_{i}\\			
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\			
		& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
		&x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
		&x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
		&x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~5\\ 
		\end{array}
	     \]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
			\text{Maximize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~6\\
			\end{array}
			\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll} 
				\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\			
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+x_{6}\geq 140\\			
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\			
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\			
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\			
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			\end{array}
			\]

&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &5 \\

Find the solution of the following system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

$$\begin{cases}
6x & - & 11y & + & 2z & - & 9t & = & 2 \\
2x & + & y & - & 2z & - & t & = & 1 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & - & 2t & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(0,\,1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(1+z,\,0,\,z,\,-z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(1-y,\,y,\,2+y,\,-y\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

Consider the function $f(x,y)=\dfrac{x-y^{4}}{x^{3}-y^{4}}$, where $y^{4} \neq x^{3}$.

Study the limits
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]$, $\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]$ and $\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y).$
answer1:
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=\frac{1}{3}$, $\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=1$, but the limit
$\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y)$ does not exist.
answer2:
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=1$, but the limit
$\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y)$ does not exist.
